title: Flashcard-based App
description:
Design a web app that uses flash cards to help people learn a foreign language. Each card shows a word or phrase in the user's language on the front. When the user hovers, taps, or clicks, the card flips to show the foreign-language equivalent, along with optional hints or example sentences.

Functional requirements:
- Allow users to browse and select decks (e.g. "Spanish A1 – Food", "German Verbs", "French Phrases")
- Fetch and render a sequence of cards for the current deck
- Support flipping cards via hover (desktop) and tap/click (desktop and mobile)
- Let users mark cards as "I knew this" / "I didn't know this" to track recall
- Persist per-user progress and difficulty (e.g. how often each card should reappear)
- Handle authentication so users can continue their progress across devices
- Provide basic stats such as cards reviewed today, accuracy, and streaks

Non-functional:
- Very low perceived latency when moving between cards (preloading, caching)
- Smooth, GPU-accelerated flip animations that stay close to 60 FPS
- Responsive layout that works well on phones, tablets, and desktops
- Accessible to keyboard users and screen readers (no hover-only behavior)
- Resilient to flaky networks (retry, optimistic updates, offline-friendly study sessions)

Data & domain constraints:
- Cards belong to decks; each card includes source language text, target language text, optional hints, and metadata (part of speech, difficulty, tags)
- Per-user state includes progress per deck, spaced-repetition metadata, and preferences (theme, flip behavior, daily goal)
- Content may be localized and should support multiple writing systems (Latin, Cyrillic, CJK, RTL scripts)

API & server–client communication:
- REST or GraphQL APIs for decks, cards, and user progress (list decks, fetch study batch, update progress)
- Endpoints optimized for study sessions (e.g. a "next batch" endpoint that applies spaced-repetition logic server-side)
- Authenticated requests for user-specific data using stateless tokens (e.g. JWT) or secure session cookies
- Optional real-time channel (WebSocket or SSE) for live sync of progress across multiple tabs/devices

Performance & UX considerations:
- Client-side caching of decks and cards (e.g. IndexedDB + HTTP caching) so revisiting a deck feels instant
- Preloading the next few cards while the user is viewing the current one
- Avoiding unnecessary re-renders when flipping or navigating between cards
- Using CSS transforms and will-change to keep flip animations smooth
- Incremental loading of large decks and strategies for updating content without disrupting ongoing sessions
